question: How should a UK Solvency II firm, the Society or managing agents demonstrate that its risk-management system is “effective” and operates on a continuous basis, specifically in relation to liquidity risk appetite and limits?
expected_answer: A UK Solvency II firm, the Society or managing agents should treat liquidity risk as a concrete application of the broader requirement to run an effective risk-management system that continuously identifies, measures, monitors, manages and reports risks and their interdependencies at both individual and aggregated levels. [#SRC:6ed49c6d770ad510] Senior management should identify material sources of liquidity risk and set prudent risk limits for those sources, so that liquidity risk can be monitored and managed in a way that aligns with the system’s continuous measurement and reporting expectations. [#SRC:6ed49c6d770ad510] To evidence “effectiveness,” the liquidity appetite statement and related limits should be embedded within the system’s strategies, processes and reporting procedures, enabling ongoing monitoring and reporting of liquidity risk both on its own and in combination with other risks. [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca] This linkage between liquidity-specific appetite/limits and the system-wide continuous risk processes helps show that liquidity risk is not handled ad hoc but is integrated into the firm’s overall risk-management framework. [#SRC:6ed49c6d770ad510]

question: For a credit union with more than £50 million in total assets that also undertakes more complex lending or invests in more complex investment products, how should it use scenario analysis to support proportionate risk management, and what escalation in PRA engagement should it anticipate if there is evidence of poor risk management/governance and it does not engage or make meaningful progress on mitigation plans?
expected_answer: A credit union in this profile should treat scenario analysis as a core tool within proportionate risk management, and it should also plan for progressively deeper PRA engagement if risk management or governance is found to be weak and remediation does not progress. [#TGT:b3afbbf8d96609e4] For credit unions with more than £50 million in total assets and/or those undertaking more complex lending (including mortgages or lending to corporates) and/or investing in more complex products (including supranational bonds, corporate bonds, bank bonds, and money market funds), the PRA expects greater engagement and expects them to run scenario analysis to assess how key strategic initiatives and external risks could affect the business. [#SRC:865973d64c7565e2] Scenario analysis can include stresses such as poorer loan book performance, higher arrears, changes to welfare benefits, changes in bank interest rates, or a greater-than-expected increase in shares, and it is presented as good practice to consider combined scenarios. question: For purposes of determining whether Articles 30–32 of MODR and Conditions Governing Business 7 apply to an arrangement, how should a firm distinguish between (i) an arrangement that is “outsourcing” under the PRA Rulebook definition (including sub-outsourcing and the “otherwise undertaken by the firm itself” test) and (ii) a non-outsourcing “third party” relationship as defined in the SS, and what role does the “recurrent or ongoing basis” consideration play in that classification?

question: When an institution applies the derogation for derivative transactions with more than one material risk driver and maps the transaction to each relevant risk category on the basis of the most material risk driver in that category, how should it determine whether its position in that most material risk driver is long or short for purposes of the Section’s definition (in the context of transactions referred to in Article 277(3))?
expected_answer: For a derivative transaction that has more than one material risk driver, the institution must first map the transaction to risk categories using the derogation: if all material risk drivers fall in one risk category, it maps the transaction once to that category using the most material risk driver; if the material risk drivers span different risk categories, it maps the transaction once to each such category using the most material risk driver within each category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] Once the relevant “most material risk driver” has been identified for the mapped risk category (or for each mapped risk category), the institution determines whether its position in that driver is long or short by assessing how the transaction’s market value responds to an increase in the value of that risk driver for transactions referred to in Article 277(3). [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301] Specifically, the position is long in the primary risk driver or the most material risk driver in the given risk category if the transaction’s market value increases when that risk driver’s value increases, and it is short if the transaction’s market value decreases when that risk driver’s value increases. [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301] This long/short determination is applied to the same risk-driver selection that the mapping rule requires (i.e., the most material risk driver used as the basis for mapping in each risk category). [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]

debug_context.source_text: Firms are strongly encouraged to combine their liquidity contingency plan 16 (also known as a contingency funding plan) and their recovery plan into one integrated document. This would ensure that the firm has a coherent process for being alerted to and addressing a liquidity stress and helps to ensure a coherent risk management framework. The PRA recognises that there may be some instances when it is necessary to maintain separate documents (eg due to requirements of local regulators), but expects this to be the exception and that any separate documents should be consistent with each other.
